content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see three pieces of tissue that have the characteristic appearance of lymph nodes. They are stained with H&E and are surrounded by adipose (fatty) tissue. The normal architecture of these lymph nodes appears to be largely replaced by a dense, basophilic (dark purple) infiltrate, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is the first and smallest lymph node on the slide, and a systematic examination of all lymph nodes is essential for accurate staging. At low power, this node appears almost completely replaced by a suspicious cellular population. I need to zoom in to assess the cytological features of these cells to confirm whether they are malignant and thus determine if the node is positive for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the second lymph node from the left. This is part of a systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes to search for metastatic cancer. I have chosen this area within the lymph node to begin my high-power examination because I need to assess the cellular composition and architecture. My goal is to look for clusters of atypical, non-lymphoid cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma, which often lodge in the subcapsular sinus or paracortical areas first. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the largest of the three lymph nodes. The specific area highlighted by the green box is at the periphery of the node, in the region of the subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area to examine because metastatic cells traveling through the lymphatic vessels typically first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus. Therefore, this is the highest-yield location to search for early or small metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area on the rightmost lymph node because it is located in the subcapsular sinus region. This is the first place tumor cells typically lodge when they metastasize to a lymph node via lymphatic drainage. The low-power view already suggests an abnormality here; the normally clear sinus space seems to be filled with cells, and the staining is less uniform than in the rest of the lymph node. This makes it a high-priority area to inspect for evidence of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see that the normal lymphoid tissue is almost entirely effaced by sheets of malignant cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular nuclear contours and scant to moderate amounts of cytoplasm. They are arranged in poorly cohesive nests and sheets. My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic, poorly differentiated carcinoma, consistent with an origin from colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see predominantly lymphoid tissue. There are recognizable lymphoid follicles, which are the dense, rounded aggregates of lymphocytes. The surrounding tissue consists of a mixed population of smaller lymphocytes. I also notice scattered dark, granular pigment, which could be anthracotic pigment or hemosiderin, a common finding in lymph nodes. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells or malignant glands in this specific field of view. My impression of this area is that it shows reactive lymphoid tissue, and it appears to be negative for metastasis. However, the entire lymph node must be scanned thoroughly to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node and the adjacent pericapsular adipose tissue on the far left. The main area shows the subcapsular sinus and the underlying lymphoid parenchyma. The parenchyma is composed of a dense population of lymphocytes. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features of metastatic carcinoma in this specific field. The impression of this particular area is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. However, the entire node must be scrutinized to rule out metastasis completely.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node at the top. Immediately beneath it, within the subcapsular sinus and extending into the lymphoid parenchyma, there are nests and clusters of atypical cells. These cells are clearly non-lymphoid; they are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, irregular, and hyperchromatic nuclei. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is definitive for metastatic carcinoma in this lymph node, making it a positive lymph node (pN+).
